name: Phantom Utilities
description: Common utility actions for phantom playbook use.

actions.description: Tests connectivity to the Phantom REST API.

actions.verbose:
Can be used with or without regex. If no regex, then just used to add text around existing string (i.e. create a query that uses a parameter from the existing datapath). If regex, findall is leveraged to find all specified groups. In either case, string format notation is used for modification (use {0} {1} {2}... etc for creating the new string).

If no regex and the output_string is 'I love {1}', and the string_to_format is 'Phantom', the resulting string is 'I love Phantom'.

To leverage today's date type 'now' in the date_value field'.

Only use date_format_input if absolutely necessary. In general, almost all types should be able to be parsed without needing to specify the format.

Use data_list if you want to add one or several values to the datapath that are all of the same type.

Example:
Adding three IPs to the datapath would be performed like so - data_list='["1.1.1.1","2.2.2.2","8.8.8.8"]', data_type='string', contains='ip'.

If you want to add multiple values to the datapath that are of different types use data_dict. Data_list and data_dict cannot be used together.

Example:
To add a string and an IP to the datapath set data_dict to '[{"data": "8.8.8.8", "data_type": "string", "contains": "ip"}, {"data": "some string", "data_type": "string"}].

If a 'contains' value is provided the 'contains' will be used in the added values datapath name. If no contains is provided then the data type will be used.

Example 1:
If contains is 'splunk query' then the data will get added to the datapath as data.*.added_data.*.splunk_query.

Example 2:
If no 'contains' is provided and the data_type being added is 'numeric' the values will be added to the datapath as data.*.added_data.*.numeric
